title: Delete direct message history without access the proper conversation_id

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
> NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace *all* the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to triage and respond quickly, so be sure to take your time filling out the report!

**Summary:** [add summary of the vulnerability]
An user can invert the user ids from a direct message URL, which is the conversation_id, and delete the whole conversation history without using the proper conversation_id and without a proper feedback to the user.

**Description:** [add more details about this vulnerability]
By having a direct message to any user, Twitter creates a specific id to this conversation. The conversation_id. This id is concatenation between the two user ids in this conversation 
separated by an hyphen . For example:

#1 - user_id = 12345
#2 - user_id = 45678
conversation_id=12345-45678

If an user invert these numbers(e.g: in our example 45678-12345) the user is asked to either accept to receive message from an undefined user or to delete it.(Attached print1). After clicking "Delete" the whole conversation history from the original conversation is deleted without ever following the happy path to proper leave a conversation.

## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Have a conversation (Direct Message) between two users.
  2. Click on the conversation to open the chat window.
  3. The URL will change and it's going to be something like: https://twitter.com/messages/123456-78910
  4. Invert those numbers on the conversation_id and the new URL will be like: https://twitter.com/messages/78910-123456 and press enter to go to this URL.
  5. User will be asked to either Accept or Delete if he want to let an undefined user to message him.  With all the options above as well, like user info. However is an undefined user. The message will be exactly:

Do you want to let  message you? They won’t know you’ve seen their message until you accept.Report conversation

You can see there is a blank space between the words 'let' and 'message'.
  6. If the user clicks on 'Delete' the original history from the original conversation is deleted(attached image: after_Deleting.png) and the feedback gave to the user doesn't mention this.

## Impact: [add why this issue matters]
Since we didn't use the proper conversation_id to delete the conversation this action might create an inconsistence on the conversations database.

## Supporting Material/References:

  * List any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)

## Impact

An attacker could create an inconsistence on the conversation data since we used a wrong conversation_id to delete the history. Maybe this issue could lead to other exploits since we had a info icon for an undefined user.
vulnerability_information_html:
NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace all the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to triage and respond quickly, so be sure to take your time filling out the report!

Summary: [add summary of the vulnerability]
An user can invert the user ids from a direct message URL, which is the conversation_id, and delete the whole conversation history without using the proper conversation_id and without a proper feedback to the user.

Description: [add more details about this vulnerability]
By having a direct message to any user, Twitter creates a specific id to this conversation. The conversation_id. This id is concatenation between the two user ids in this conversation
separated by an hyphen . For example:

1 - user_id = 12345

2 - user_id = 45678

conversation_id=12345-45678

If an user invert these numbers(e.g: in our example 45678-12345) the user is asked to either accept to receive message from an undefined user or to delete it.(Attached print1). After clicking "Delete" the whole conversation history from the original conversation is deleted without ever following the happy path to proper leave a conversation.

Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Have a conversation (Direct Message) between two users.
  2. Click on the conversation to open the chat window.
  3. The URL will change and it's going to be something like: https://twitter.com/messages/123456-78910
  4. Invert those numbers on the conversation_id and the new URL will be like: https://twitter.com/messages/78910-123456 and press enter to go to this URL.
  5. User will be asked to either Accept or Delete if he want to let an undefined user to message him. With all the options above as well, like user info. However is an undefined user. The message will be exactly:

Do you want to let message you? They won’t know you’ve seen their message until you accept.Report conversation

You can see there is a blank space between the words 'let' and 'message'.

  1. If the user clicks on 'Delete' the original history from the original conversation is deleted(attached image: after_Deleting.png) and the feedback gave to the user doesn't mention this.

Impact: [add why this issue matters]

Since we didn't use the proper conversation_id to delete the conversation this action might create an inconsistence on the conversations database.

Supporting Material/References:

  • List any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)

Impact

An attacker could create an inconsistence on the conversation data since we used a wrong conversation_id to delete the history. Maybe this issue could lead to other exploits since we had a info icon for an undefined user.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @soareswallace,

We were able to reproduce the behavior you described and will get back to you when we have more information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @soareswallace,

We were able to reproduce the behavior you described and will get back to you when we have more information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message: Ok, also I forgot to mention the issue only happens in new Twitter GUI.
activities.markdown_message: Ok, also I forgot to mention the issue only happens in new Twitter GUI.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
I found another side affect of this issue. iOS app isn't receiving direct messages after we delete the conversation by using a wrong conversation_id. 

After deleting the conversation by using the wrong conversation_id I started another DM with the same users. From the session we used to reproduce the issue I start to send messages. The receiver can see the messages from the web UI. However if the receiver uses the iOS app, neither the messages or the conversation is showing up. Plus, if I start the conversation from the iOS(after send new messages), the previous messages that we saw on the web UI will not show on the conversation.

Please, if you have any questions about how to reproduce this new scenario don't hesitate in asking.
activities.markdown_message:
I found another side affect of this issue. iOS app isn't receiving direct messages after we delete the conversation by using a wrong conversation_id.

After deleting the conversation by using the wrong conversation_id I started another DM with the same users. From the session we used to reproduce the issue I start to send messages. The receiver can see the messages from the web UI. However if the receiver uses the iOS app, neither the messages or the conversation is showing up. Plus, if I start the conversation from the iOS(after send new messages), the previous messages that we saw on the web UI will not show on the conversation.

Please, if you have any questions about how to reproduce this new scenario don't hesitate in asking.

activities.message:
Steps:
1 - Delete the conversation using the procedure that I describe above.
2 - From the same session you use to delete the conversation by using the wrong conversation_id initiate a new DM with the same users from the conversation deleted.
3 - From that same session(consider as sender) just send a couple of messages.
4 - The receiver will be able to see the messages from the web UI.
5 - With the receiver user, log in on the iOS app.
6 - The receiver user will not be able to see the same messages in iOS app. Actually even if we send a bunch of messages(sender -> receiver) the receiver will not be notified.
7 - Start a new conversation(receiver -> sender) and send some messages.
8 - The previous messages that we sent on step 3 will not being show up on the messages history.

Any messages sent by the users from the web UI will not sync will the messages on the iOS app.

Please, if you have any questions about how to reproduce this new scenario don't hesitate in asking.
activities.markdown_message:
Steps:
1 - Delete the conversation using the procedure that I describe above.
2 - From the same session you use to delete the conversation by using the wrong conversation_id initiate a new DM with the same users from the conversation deleted.
3 - From that same session(consider as sender) just send a couple of messages.
4 - The receiver will be able to see the messages from the web UI.
5 - With the receiver user, log in on the iOS app.
6 - The receiver user will not be able to see the same messages in iOS app. Actually even if we send a bunch of messages(sender -> receiver) the receiver will not be notified.
7 - Start a new conversation(receiver -> sender) and send some messages.
8 - The previous messages that we sent on step 3 will not being show up on the messages history.

Any messages sent by the users from the web UI will not sync will the messages on the iOS app.

Please, if you have any questions about how to reproduce this new scenario don't hesitate in asking.

activities.message: Guys, the bug is still reproducible. Have you guys work on a fix? I agree that is not a top priority, but I think it should be on your roadmap.

activities.message: This issue is fixed, backend wise, however the UI still crashes in not showing messages.
activities.markdown_message: This issue is fixed, backend wise, however the UI still crashes in not showing messages.
